In a monoid $M$, an element $b \in M$ is called an inverse of a given element $a \in M$ if $ab = e = ba$. The element $b$, if it exists, is uniquely determined by $a$ and is denoted by $a^{-1}$.
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A left coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $aH = \{ah; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called finitely generated if there exist finitely many elements $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n})$.

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Principal Ideal Domain (ID: 3) is a specialization of a Commutative Ring (ID: 2) because it inherits all properties of a commutative ring and adds additional conditions, specifically being an integral domain and every ideal being principal.
